profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Cornwall, Conn., December 25, 1782; attended the public schools, and was graduated from Williams College, Williamstown, Mass., in 1804; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1807 and commenced practice in Pompey Hill, Onondaga County, N.Y.; elected as a Republican to the Fourteenth Congress (March 4, 1815-March 3, 1817); was not a candidate for renomination in 1816; postmaster of Pompey Hill 1817-1838; district attorney of Onondaga County 1818-1833; master of chancery of Onondaga County 1818-1822; delegate to the State constitutional convention in 1821; member of the State assembly 1823 and 1838-1840; served in the State senate in 1827; unsuccessful candidate for election in 1838 to the Twenty-sixth Congress; elected as a Whig to the Twenty-seventh Congress (March 4, 1841-March 3, 1843); was not a candidate for renomination in 1842; resumed the practice of law; died in Pompey, Onondaga County, N.Y., September 16, 1853; interment in Pompey Hill Cemetery.

note.content: One of two elected to represent twenty-third district.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Birdseye, Victory. Remarks of Mr. Birdseye of New York, on the Bankrupt Bill. Delivered in the House of Representatives, in Committee of the Whole, August 13, 1841. Washington: Printed by Gales and Seaton, 1841.

researchRecord.name: 1815-1816, 1 folder.
researchRecord.description: Letters of Victory Birdseye and letters received; also includes a short biographical sketch.

researchRecord.name: In the Skaneateles Library Association Records, 1803-1984, 4 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers include copies and typescripts of Victory Birdsell family letters, 1815-1843, mostly from Victory Birdseye to his wife Electa Beebee Birdseye at Pompey, NY, while he was serving in Congress in Washington, DC, 1815-1816. The correspondence also includes discussion of other Congressmen, politics, and Washington life.
